events.title: The birth
events.text: In 1799, inventor George Medhurst proposed an idea to move goods through cast-iron pipes using air pressure.

events.title: Applied Theory
events.text: Throughout the mid-1850s, several more pneumatic railways were built in Dublin, London, and Paris.
events.more: The London Pneumatic Despatch system was meant to transport parcels, but it was large enough to carry people, too. To mark its opening, the Duke of Buckingham traveled through it in 1865.

events.title: Air in Action
events.text: In the mid-1860s, South London constructed the Crystal Palace atmospheric railway, which ran through a park. A fan, which measured 22 feet in diameter, propelled the train.
events.more: On return journeys, the fan's blades reversed, sucking the carriage backwards.

events.title: The First Prototype
events.text: In 1910, American rocket pioneer Robert Goddard designed a train that would go from Boston to New York in just 12 minutes. Though it was never built, it would've floated on magnets inside a vacuum-sealed tunnel.

events.title: Modern Ideal's Birth
events.text: By the end of the 19th century, most major cities used pneumatic tube systems to transport mail and other messages.
events.more: Some still exist today at banks, hospitals, and factories. NASA started using pneumatic tubes as intra-office communication in the 1960s. And until 2011, a (now-closed) McDonald's in Edina, Minnesota used them to deliver Big Macs and fries to customers at its drive-through.

events.title: The New Identity
events.text: Elon Musk published his proposal for the Hyperloop in a 57-page white paper. According to his design, sealed pods containing 28 people each would whisk through tubes.
events.more: A trip from NYC to DC would take 29 minutes, he tweeted in 2017. Hyperloop Transportation Technologies, a startup building off Musk's concept, is creating a 5-mile test track for a Hyperloop system in Quay Valley, California. Construction began in 2016, and the company is aiming for the train to reach 760 mph.

events.title: First Successful test
events.text: In July 2017, a startup called Hyperloop One successfully tested a full-scale system on its DevLoop test track in Nevada. Using maglevs, the vehicle reached a top speed of 70 mph.
events.more: The company hopes to reach 250 mph.
